title: iPhone XS vs Samsung Galaxy S9 | Trusted Reviews

## Samsung Galaxy S9 vs iPhone XS – Should one of these be your next phone?

Putting the Samsung Galaxy S9 vs iPhone XS and deciding which one you should
buy out two of the biggest flagship phones of 2018

Apple’s latest devices are now available to pre-order. You’ve got the [iPhone
XS,](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/iphone-xs-release-date-specs-price-
uk-3551351) iPhone XS Max and [Apple Watch
4](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/apple-watch-series-4-3487177). Plus
there’s the iPhone XR coming in October. But how does it compare to the
[Samsung Galaxy S9](https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/samsung-galaxy-s9)?

**Related:[iPhone XR vs iPhone XS vs iPhone XS
Max](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/iphone-xr-vs-iphone-xs-vs-iphone-xs-
max-3565104)**

## **iPhone XS vs Samsung Galaxy S9 – Design**

Both flagship devices are constructed from metal and glass, but that’s where
the similarities end. The Samsung Galaxy S9 is all curves and slopes, whereas
the iPhone is flat and rounded.

The stainless steel rim of the iPhone XS is made to be seen, while the
aluminium rim sandwiching the front and rear of the Galaxy S9 almost melts
into the glass.

**Related:[iPhone XR](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/iphone-xr-release-
date-specs-price-3579137)**

![iphone
XS](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

### The OnePlus 6T ditched the headphone jack, CEO Pete Lau tells us why

](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/ceo-pete-lau-oneplus-6t-headphone-jack-
wireless-charging-3612475 "The OnePlus 6T ditched the headphone jack, CEO Pete
Lau tells us why")

  * 

Another difference between the two devices can be seen on the front. The
iPhone XS adopts the notched screen, featuring a cut-out at the top that
contains the front-facing camera. The Galaxy S9, on the other hand, extends
the bezel slightly to fit this functionality in. Not everyone will love the
notch since it impedes what’s on the screen. Personally, we prefer the
approach taken by Samsung.

The other reason Apple opts for the notch solution is the sheer amount of tech
required for its [Face ID](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/face-
id-3286453) facial recognition to work. Apple has completely ditched all other
forms of biometric security, so the only way of unlocking the iPhone – other
than a PIN – is with your visage.

**Related:[Best smartphones](https://www.trustedreviews.com/best/best-
smartphone-3431175)**

Focusing on one form of security means that Apple’s solution works far better
than that of Samsung. Both the iris scanner and face recognition on the Galaxy
prove hit or miss. Samsung does also have a fingerprint sensor, which some
users will appreciate.

Both handsets pack water-resistant
[IP68](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinion/what-is-ip68-ip-ratings-
explained-2947135) bodies and Qi wireless charging, plus speakers that push
the sound towards your face. The Galaxy S9 is the only one of the two to boast
a headphone jack, however.

## **iPhone XS vs Samsung Galaxy S9 – Specs and features**

| **iPhone XS** | **Galaxy S9**  
---|---|---  
**Display** |  5.8-inch 19.5:9  
1124 x 2436 AMOLED | 5.8-inch sAMOLED  
**Processor** |  Apple A12 | 845/Exynos 9810  
**RAM** |  4GB | 4GB  
**Rear camera** |  Dual 12-megapixels | 12-megapixels  
**Front camera** |  7-megapixels | 8-megapixels  
**Battery** |  TBC | 3000mAh  
**Software** |  iOS 12 | Android 8  
**Storage** |  64/256/512GB | 64/256GB  
  
Powering the Samsung Galaxy S9 is a selection of top-end specs: Snapdragon
845/Exynos 9810 CPU (depending on which part of the world you’re in), 4GB of
RAM, a modem with support for Gigabit LTE, and all the latest Bluetooth and
Wi-Fi standards. There’s also a slot for expandable storage – a feature you’ll
never see on an iPhone.

Another high-end spec is the screen. On the front of the Samsung Galaxy S9 is
a 5.8-inch [OLED](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/oled-vs-qled-3530313)
panel with a QHD+ resolution, offering 1000 nits of brightness, and support
for [HDR](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinion/hdr-tv-high-dynamic-
television-explained-2927035) from Prime Video, YouTube and Netflix. It’s a
glorious display that’s one of the best around. There’s a larger Galaxy S9
Plus available, too, sporting a 6.2-inch screen.

The iPhone XS also uses OLED tech for its display and, again, is available in
two sizes. There’s the regular iPhone XS with a 5.8-inch display and the
larger iPhone XS Max with a 6.5-inch screen. Like the Galaxy S9, these devices
support HDR through the Dolby Vision format.

The iPhone XS (and the XS Max) runs the new [A12
Bionic](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/apple-a12-3462239) 7nm chip from
Apple, along with 4GB RAM and comes with storage ranging from 64GB to 512GB.

**Related:[iPad Pro 2018](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/ipad-
pro-2018-release-date-specs-price-3482812)**

![Samsung Galaxy S9
front](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

We’ve tested the Galaxy S9 thoroughly and found it impressed in the
performance stakes, so it will be interesting to see how the iPhone XS and
iPhone XS Max compare.

Both the iPhone XS and Samsung Galaxy S9 have voice assistants in Siri and
Bixby respectively, with the S9 also able to double-up as a desktop computer
thanks to [DeX](https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/samsung-dex).

## **iPhone XS vs Samsung Galaxy S9 – Camera**

The biggest update the to Samsung Galaxy S9 has been its camera. The
12-megapixel sensor has a variable aperture lens that can switch between f/1.5
and f/2.4, depending on the environment and what you’re shooting.

This is clever, and it works well in practice. If the room you’re shooting in
is dark, the lens will open up to f/1.5 and let more light into the sensor,
resulting in a brighter picture. When the light is better, the lens will
shrink down to f/2.4.

![iPhone
XS](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

The Galaxy S9 also supports 4K video at 60fps, super slow-motion recording,
and features an 8-megapixel camera around the front for selfies. It’s a decent
camera setup, but one that even so has been beaten by the [Google Pixel
2](https://www.trustedreviews.com/reviews/google-pixel-2).

The camera also happens to be one of the biggest areas of improvement for the
iPhone XS.

You’ve still got two 12-megapixel sensors, one for regular photos and one for
zoomed shots, but Apple says the sensor has been completely rebuilt with
larger pixels. The front-facing 7-megapixel camera is also faster than before
and it can now shoot video with stereo-sound.

Like the Google Pixel 2, the iPhone XS uses computational photography and the
neural engine inside the A12 Bionic to power the new Smart-HDR mode. This
takes multiple shots as soon as you open the camera app and it’ll even shoot a
few overexposed shots to improve the highlights and shadows.

Both phones have a portrait mode and they both allow you to alter the strength
of the bokeh effect in post-production.

## **iPhone XS vs Samsung Galaxy S9 – Price**

When it launched in April 2018, the Samsung Galaxy S9 retailed for £749 for
the regular version and £869 for the larger Plus-sized version.

The iPhone XS is a lot pricier, starting at £999 for the base 64GB version and
rising to £1099 for the larger 6.5-inch Max. If you want more storage you’ll
have to pay £1149 (256GB) or £1449 for the 512GB version.

## **Early verdict**

Neither of these phones is a huge update over their predecessors, but they
still have upgrades to important aspects, such as the camera. Whether the
iPhone XS is worth over £250 more than the Galaxy S9 remains to be seen.
